subject: Re: [junit] Re: @Test only work with runtime exception ?
msgSnippet: Kiwi, Good question.  JUnit 4 assumes that subclasses of TestCase should be run as JUnit 3 test classes, even if there are JUnit 4 annotations floating around.
messageBody:
Kiwi,

Good question. JUnit 4 assumes that subclasses of TestCase should be run as
JUnit 3 test classes, even if there are JUnit 4 annotations floating
around. To override this, you can specify the runner directly*

@RunWith(TestClassRunner.class)
public class JustATest extends TestCase {...}

That said, you may also want to, as you said, compose in an object or two
that give you the abstractions you need, rather than getting them through
inheritance on an AbstractTestCase. I've found that the abstractions I
create in this way are more easily re-usable and re-mixable. Good luck,

David Saff

* warning, this is currently an internal class name, and will change and
become public, in 4.4
